headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk a little bit about what pricing looks like going forward with the recent steel inflation? And then Susan, I know you just said you expect steel inflation at some point. What does that mean for pricing going forward?
componenttext: I wanted to talk a little bit about what pricing looks like going forward with the recent steel inflation? And then Susan, I know you just said you expect steel inflation at some point. What does that mean for pricing going forward?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Leah, this's Karl. Steel is really tough for us to forecast. Susan's commentary on an expectation of ultimate inflation is kind of steeped in the thought process that it can't go much lower at this point, you know that we had a little bit of a head fake o
componenttext: Leah, this's Karl. Steel is really tough for us to forecast. Susan's commentary on an expectation of ultimate inflation is kind of steeped in the thought process that it can't go much lower at this point, you know that we had a little bit of a head fake on steel, where scrap traded up little north of $50 a ton in the second quarter. We expected that there would be inflation off of that. It did not take place. Actually scrap traded down about $20 a ton in September and now $20 in October. So there is a little bit of softness. At the current price of scrap, scrap probably won't be collected, so hopefully, into 2017, that there will be a resurgence in demand. There'll be an equalization of pricing. As odd as it sounds, we badly want inflation that admittedly, there's a 90-day lag on pass-through. While we appreciate the short-term margins that we booked in the third quarter of this year, we want inflation. We need inflation, and we expect it to some degree next year, but to predict timing is a real challenge.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes the line of Budd Bugatch with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes the line of Budd Bugatch with Raymond James.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Bobby filling in for Budd. I just wanted to touch real quick on the adjustable base business. I believe this is kind of a -- I think, I believe it's the second quarter in a row units were down, is that just a function of tougher comps? Maybe some
componenttext: This is Bobby filling in for Budd. I just wanted to touch real quick on the adjustable base business. I believe this is kind of a -- I think, I believe it's the second quarter in a row units were down, is that just a function of tougher comps? Maybe some competition to lower price point? Or are you seeing a change in consumer behavior and some pressure in the attachment rates?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bobby, actually, all those things. That as you know, the comp was tough. Adjustables were up 55% in 3Q '15. Some of that was a pull forward by a large customer of ours that was about to go through an ERP implementation, so they pulled forward some 4Q '15
componenttext: Bobby, actually, all those things. That as you know, the comp was tough. Adjustables were up 55% in 3Q '15. Some of that was a pull forward by a large customer of ours that was about to go through an ERP implementation, so they pulled forward some 4Q '15 volume into 3Q '15. So that made that comp that much tougher. There's no question that we're being impacted by soft market demand. We're also going through a conversion of adjustables being sold through OEM mattress manufacturers and taking out that inefficiency and now being sold directly to retail. So therefore, you should see significantly fewer adjustable sold through the residential side of the business, which as the commentary previous stated that those, as you know, those were just pass-through sales at very little margin impact on the residential side, but certainly there were a lot of sales dollars associated with that. The product is manufactured in the commercial segment, will now primarily be sold out of the commercial segment. And we're going through this transition where we're ramping down inventories at the OEM side, ramping up inventories at the direct retail. So mix that all together, we have not lost share, by the way, at the low end, you made reference there that there's no question that AUSPs are dropping in adjustables, which is probably a good thing for the business from a long-term perspective then that it means longer term, there'll be more units sold. But we are not disadvantaged in that equation.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given that the ASUPs are dropping as you're referencing, have you seen attachment rates start to pick up at the lower end of the mattress industry, the sub-1,000 mattresses?
componenttext: Given that the ASUPs are dropping as you're referencing, have you seen attachment rates start to pick up at the lower end of the mattress industry, the sub-1,000 mattresses?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. There is no question that there's a pick up at the lower end. And there probably is a little bit of softness at the ultra-premium end. That ultra-premium consumer is probably a little bit of, little cautious. And I would think that, well, you heard o
componenttext: Yes. There is no question that there's a pick up at the lower end. And there probably is a little bit of softness at the ultra-premium end. That ultra-premium consumer is probably a little bit of, little cautious. And I would think that, well, you heard on Tempurs' call yesterday that they made reference to the fact that their attach rates were less at premium price points. We're seeing that across the market.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. I appreciate the color. And then maybe lastly for me. On -- At the Investor Day, we saw some exciting things with Quantum Edge and micro coils inside the Bedding division. Can you maybe update us on how the penetration is going for those items? And
componenttext: Good. I appreciate the color. And then maybe lastly for me. On -- At the Investor Day, we saw some exciting things with Quantum Edge and micro coils inside the Bedding division. Can you maybe update us on how the penetration is going for those items? And maybe what the kind of -- what we might see in our next year for some of those?

componenttextpreview: Bobby, you're really becoming a bedding guy. I appreciate the fact that you thought that was exciting because it is really exciting. But anyway, go ahead, Perry.
componenttext: Bobby, you're really becoming a bedding guy. I appreciate the fact that you thought that was exciting because it is really exciting. But anyway, go ahead, Perry.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bobby, it's -- we are seeing some pretty steady growth on the upholstery layer replacement side of our business, which is basically our nano coils and our Softek-type pads in the lower height pocket springs that we manufacture. Quantum Edge is -- I really
componenttext: Bobby, it's -- we are seeing some pretty steady growth on the upholstery layer replacement side of our business, which is basically our nano coils and our Softek-type pads in the lower height pocket springs that we manufacture. Quantum Edge is -- I really am excited about, I think as we get into next year, I believe that we will see that pacing really quicken. That obviously gives us content gains. It also will affect our average unit selling prices going forward. There'll be a little bit of a disconnect there with where we are now. But we think there's some really strong introductions going to happen in the first part of the year in Las Vegas, and we're excited about being able to replace a lot of that foam itch with spring products.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could talk a little bit about the aerospace business. Since I guess 2 quarters in a row here we are negative. Anything in particular going on? Or is it just some lumpy orders?
componenttext: I wonder if you could talk a little bit about the aerospace business. Since I guess 2 quarters in a row here we are negative. Anything in particular going on? Or is it just some lumpy orders?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Dillard. Actually, we're experiencing some softness in our welded tube business, the straight tube business, which was the first acquisition Western, where there's a little reduction in selling price. And candidly, we've lost a little bit of market sh
componenttext: No, Dillard. Actually, we're experiencing some softness in our welded tube business, the straight tube business, which was the first acquisition Western, where there's a little reduction in selling price. And candidly, we've lost a little bit of market share. In the seamless tube, the French business, that business is performing really, really well. As is the value-added businesses that we added subsequent bolt-on acquisitions. So it's the original base business where we're experiencing some softness. The market is lumpy over time. But 2 quarters in a row, I can't blame on lumpiness.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Keith Hughes with SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to drill down a little bit on, Karl, on your discussion on the adjustables. Specific to Leggett, are you having any shifts of your customer accounts you've won or accounts you've lost, things of that nature? And also just do you expect overall
componenttext: Just wanted to drill down a little bit on, Karl, on your discussion on the adjustables. Specific to Leggett, are you having any shifts of your customer accounts you've won or accounts you've lost, things of that nature? And also just do you expect overall the price point of the adjustables to continue to fall. I think that's what you're saying. And does that mean some of the functionality in adjustables will go away?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keith, thanks for the questions. That -- yes, there are customer wins and loses all the time, especially as we migrate -- the industry migrates from a predominantly distributed through OEM to predominantly distributed through retail. So there's those shif
componenttext: Keith, thanks for the questions. That -- yes, there are customer wins and loses all the time, especially as we migrate -- the industry migrates from a predominantly distributed through OEM to predominantly distributed through retail. So there's those shifts in a magnitude of volume through each channel changing pretty significantly. Interestingly enough, as the product is decreasing or let's call it more fully penetrated in terms of units and price points. The features aren't changing all that much. That as you drop into the promotional price points historically that would be a wired bit. It's a wireless product today. The head-only product hasn't sold significantly well. So as electronics -- the cost of electronics drop, the significant volume growth from the macro market in terms of throughput through assets that the consumer is not losing much functionality as the pricing -- at retail drops.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: And just one other question on bedding. The Comfort Core negative 2%, kind of looking like the industry right now and its been well outperformed or do you think that's kind of hit and stop in terms of its market share?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: No. Keith, this's Perry. I don't. We're in the mid- 30s now as far as percentage of springs that we sell that are in the Comfort Core category. We have debates among ourselves as to how strong it will get in the U.S. market. But I'd certainly think we've got opportunities to go, kind of well north of 40%. Some people say it could be 50% in the future. But I don't think we're by any means done with the growth of that category. And like I said, just a little bit ago, I don't think we're -- we've even scratched the surface with the content gain that we look to gain over the next couple of years.
